tit.e: Ryosei province (province governed according to Ritsuryo codes)
tit.cmt: 後列に説明があるので（）内は削除

sen.j: 令制国（りょうせいこく）とは、律令制に基づいて設置された日本の地方行政区分である。
sen.e: Ryosei province (province governed according to Ritsuryo codes)
Ryosei-koku designates Japanese province that was established under the ritsuryo codes.
sen.cmt: 前列のコピーになっています→全体を訳し直しました。
sen.e: Ryosei-koku designates Japanese province that was established under the ritsuryo codes.

sen.j: 奈良時代から明治初期まで、日本の地理的区分の基本単位であった。
sen.e: Ryousei (Ritsuryo codes) system had been the basic unit of geographical division in Japan since Nara period to the beginning of Meiji period.
Ryousei province had been the basic unit of geographical division in Japan since Nara period to the beginning of Meiji period.
sen.cmt: ・(Ritsuryo codes) →削除しました（他の列で説明があるので）・system→province（主語は「令制国」です）
sen.e: Ryousei province had been the basic unit of geographical division in Japan since Nara period to the beginning of Meiji period.

sen.j: 律令国（りつりょうこく）ともいう。
sen.e: Ryosei province is also called Ritsuryo province.
Ryosei province is also called Ritsuryo province.
Ryosei province is also called Ritsuryo province.

sen.j: 蝦夷国は正式な令制国ではなく俗称であり、また琉球国は当初大和朝廷の影響が及んでいなかった。
sen.e: Ezo province was not a formal area division, but a common area name, and Ryukyu province was not originally under the influence of Yamato Imperial Court. Therefore, Ryukyu province is not included in the Ryosei province here in this article.
Ezo province was not a formal area division under the ryosei system but a common area name, and Ryukyu province was not originally under the influence of Yamato Imperial Court.
sen.cmt: ・under the ryosei systemを補完一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Ezo province was not a formal area division under the ryosei system but a common area name, and Ryukyu province was not originally under the influence of Yamato Imperial Court.

sen.j: このため、ここには含まない。
sen.e: Therefore, these provinces are not included in the Ryosei province here in this article.
sen.cmt: ・一原文一訳文の例外対処・Ryukyu province is→these provinces are（主語は琉球国と蝦夷国）
sen.e: Therefore, these provinces are not included in the Ryosei province here in this article.

sen.j: 蝦夷国は1869年に北海道 (令制)の名称で広域地方行政区画とされ、琉球国は1871年に令制国として鹿児島県に編入し、後に沖縄県とした（世界大百科事典参考）。
sen.e: Ezo province was defined as wide area local administrative division in the name of Hokkaido(Ryosei province), and Ryukyu province was included in Kagoshima Prefecture as a Ryosei province in 1871 (for reference; world big encyclopedia).

Ezo province was defined as wide area local administrative division in the name of Hokkaido (Ryosei), and Ryukyu province was included in Kagoshima Prefecture as a Ryosei province in 1871 (for reference; world unagridged encyclopedia).
sen.cmt: ・(Ryosei province)→(Ryosei)・world big encyclopedia→world unabridged encyclopedia・（）内の余分なスペース削除
sen.e: Ezo province was defined as wide area local administrative division in the name of Hokkaido (Ryosei), and Ryukyu province was included in Kagoshima Prefecture as a Ryosei province in 1871 (for reference; world unagridged encyclopedia).

sen.j: 令制国の行政機関を国衙（こくが）または国庁（こくちょう）といい、国衙の所在地や国衙を中心とする都市域を国府（こくふ）といった。
sen.e: The administrative organ in a Ryosei province was called Kokuga or Kokucho, and the city area centering around Kokuga and the location of Kokuga was called Kokufu.
The administrative organ in a Ryosei province was called Kokuga or Kokucho, and the city area centering around Kokuga and the location of Kokuga was called Kokufu.
The administrative organ in a Ryosei province was called Kokuga or Kokucho, and the city area centering around Kokuga and the location of Kokuga was called Kokufu.

sen.j: 国府は府中と呼ばれることもあった。
sen.e: Kokufu was also called Fuchu
Kokufu was also called Fuchu
Kokufu was also called Fuchu

sen.j: 用語
sen.e: Definition of the term " Ryosei province"
Definition
Definition

sen.j: 令制国が行政体・地理区分の基本単位として用いられていた時代には、正式にも慣用的にも「国」とだけ呼ばれていた。
sen.e: In the age when the term " Ryosei province " was used as the basic unit for administrative and geographical division, it used to be called only as " province " officially and customarily.
In the age when the term " Ryosei province " was used as the basic unit for administrative and geographical division, it used to be called only as 'province' officially and customarily.
sen.cmt: 引用符を修正しました。
sen.e: In the age when the term " Ryosei province " was used as the basic unit for administrative and geographical division, it used to be called only as 'province' officially and customarily.

sen.j: 後代の20世紀には「旧国」「旧国名」とも呼んだ。
sen.e: Later in the 20th century, they called it as " old province " or " old province name. "
Later in the 20th century, they called it as 'old province' or 'old province name.'
sen.cmt: 引用符を修正しました。
sen.e: Later in the 20th century, they called it as 'old province' or 'old province name.'

sen.j: 律令のうち、令によって規定される制度を令制というので、令制の国を令制国と呼ぶ。
sen.e: Later in the 20th century, they called it as " old province " or " old province name. "
Among the ritsuryo, the system defined by ryo is ryo system (ryosei), so the province under the ryo system is called ryosei province.
sen.cmt: 前列のコピーになっています→全体を訳し直しました。
sen.e: Among the ritsuryo, the system defined by ryo is ryo system (ryosei), so the province under the ryo system is called ryosei province.

sen.j: 「令制国」という語は、20世紀末に用いられ始めた歴史学の用語であり、早いものでは1980年代半ば頃から使用例が現れている。
sen.e: The term " Ryosei province" is the historical academic term that started to be used at the end of 20th century and examples for use of the term " Ryosei province " appeared in the middle of 1980s.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の」例外対処
sen.e: The term " Ryosei province" is the historical academic term that started to be used at the end of 20th century and early examples for use of the term " Ryosei province " appeared in the middle of 1980s.

The term " Ryosei province" is the historical academic term that started to be used at the end of 20th century and early examples for use of the term " Ryosei province " appeared in the middle of 1980s.

sen.j: しかし1984年2月に吉川弘文館から発行された『国史大辞典 (昭和時代)第4巻』では令制国のことは「国」の項目で説明されており、文中にも「令制国」と呼ぶといった説明はない。
sen.e: However, according to the "" Japanese history big dictionary (Showa era) the 4th volume "" published by Yoshikawa kobunkan in February, 1984, ryosei province is explained in the article of " province ", in which the term " Ryosei province " is not used.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の」例外対処
sen.e: However, according to the "Japanese history unabridged dictionary (Showa era), the 4th volume" published by Yoshikawa kobunkan in February 1984, ryosei province is explained in the article of 'province' in which the term 'Ryosei province' is not used.
sen.cmt: ・引用符を修正しました・big dictionary→unabridged dictionary・コンマを調整しました
sen.e: However, according to the "Japanese history unabridged dictionary (Showa era), the 4th volume" published by Yoshikawa kobunkan in February 1984, ryosei province is explained in the article of 'province' in which the term 'Ryosei province' is not used.

sen.j: 令制国の成立
sen.e: Establishment of ryosei province
Establishment of Ryosei Province
sen.cmt: 小タイトルなので単語の頭を大文字に
sen.e: Establishment of Ryosei Province

sen.j: 日本の古代には、令制国が成立する前に、土着の豪族である国造（くにのみやつこ）が治める国と、県主（あがたぬし）が治める県（あがた）が並立した段階があった。
sen.e: In Japanese ancient times, before the era of Ryosei province establishment, there was the stage in which the provinces ruled by kuninomiyatsuko or powerful regional clans and the areas ruled by agatanushi or local influential persons were compatible.

In Japanese ancient times, before the era of Ryosei province establishment, there was the stage in which the province ruled by kuninomiyatsuko or powerful regional clans and the agata (territory) ruled by agatanushi or local influential persons were compatible.
sen.cmt: ・the areas→the agata (territory)（用語共有を参照）
sen.e: In Japanese ancient times, before the era of Ryosei province establishment, there was the stage in which the province ruled by kuninomiyatsuko or powerful regional clans and the agata (territory) ruled by agatanushi or local influential persons were compatible.

sen.j: それに対して、令制国は、中央から派遣された国司が治める国である。
sen.e: On the contrary, a Ryosei province was the area ruled by a provincial governor who was dispatched from central government.
On the contrary, a Ryosei province was the area ruled by kokushi or provincial governor who was dispatched from central government.
sen.cmt: 前列では日本語読みで官職を訳出しているので、それに合わせてkokushi orを挿入しました。
sen.e: On the contrary, a Ryosei province was the area ruled by kokushi or provincial governor who was dispatched from central government.

sen.j: 令制の国が何時成立したについての定説はまだないが、『日本書紀』には、645年の大化の改新の際に、東国に国司を派遣したという記事があり、飛鳥から出土した木簡削片に「伊勢国」「近淡□（海）」などと書かれていることが分かっている。
sen.e: There is no established explanation when ryousei provinces were established, but in Chronicles of Japan, there is an article in which at the times of Taika Reform, they sent provincial governors to eastern provinces, and it is known that on the narrow strips of wood unearthed at Asuka, the wording with " Ise Province", " Kin awaguchi (sea) and so on were written.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の」例外対処
sen.e: There is no established explanation when ryousei provinces were established, but in "Nihonshoki" (the Chronicles of Japan), there is an article in which at the times of the Taika Reform in 645, they sent provincial governors to eastern provinces, and it is known that on the narrow strips of wood unearthed at Asuka, the words 'Ise Province', 'Omi Province' and so on were written.
sen.cmt: ・"Nihonshoki"を補完・in 645を訳出・余分なスペースを削除・wording with→words・引用符・ Kin awaguchi (sea)→'Omi Province'http://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E8%BF%91%E6%B1%9F%E5%9B%BD
sen.e: There is no established explanation when ryousei provinces were established, but in "Nihonshoki" (the Chronicles of Japan), there is an article in which at the times of the Taika Reform in 645, they sent provincial governors to eastern provinces, and it is known that on the narrow strips of wood unearthed at Asuka, the words 'Ise Province', 'Omi Province' and so on were written.

sen.j: したがって、天武朝の初め670年代には成立していたと考えられている。
sen.e: Therefore, it is considered that the Ryousei province was established in the 670s.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の」例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, it is considered that the Ryosei province was established in the 670s, the beginning of the Reign of Emperor Tenmu.
sen.cmt: ・Ryousei→Ryosei・「天武朝の初め」を訳出しました
sen.e: Therefore, it is considered that the Ryosei province was established in the 670s, the beginning of the Reign of Emperor Tenmu.

sen.j: 令制国が確実に成立したと言えるのは、701年（大宝 (日本)元年）に制定された大宝律令からである。
sen.e: It can be said after the completion of the Taiho Code in 701 that ritsuryo provinces were surely established.
It can be said that ritsuryo provinces were surely established after the completion of the Taiho Code in 701.
sen.cmt: 節の順序を変更しました
sen.e: It can be said that ritsuryo provinces were surely established after the completion of the Taiho Code in 701.

sen.j: 故に、令制国の成立時期は早ければ645年、遅ければ701年となる。
sen.e: Therefore, the time for ritsuryo province establishment was in 645 in early case, and in 701 in later case.
Therefore, the time for ritsuryo province establishment was in 645 in earlier case, and in 701 in later case.
Therefore, the time for ritsuryo province establishment was in 645 in earlier case, and in 701 in later case.

sen.j: この間の段階的な制度変化の結果であった可能性も高い。
sen.e: It was highly possible that the time for ryosei province establishment was due to the result of system change during this period.
It was highly possible that the time for ryosei province establishment was due to the result of the gradual change of the system during this period.
sen.cmt: ・「段階的な」を訳出：system change→the gradual change of the system
sen.e: It was highly possible that the time for ryosei province establishment was due to the result of the gradual change of the system during this period.

sen.j: 令制国成立に伴い分割された国
sen.e: Provinces that were separated with the Rosei province establishment;
Provinces that were separated with the Rosei province establishment;
Provinces that were separated with the Rosei province establishment;

sen.j: 毛野国（上野国、下野国）
sen.e: Keno Province (Kouzuke Province, Shimotsuke Province)
Keno Province (Kouzuke Province, Shimotsuke Province)
Keno Province (Kouzuke Province, Shimotsuke Province)

sen.j: 総国（上総国、下総国、安房国）
sen.e: Soo Province (Kazusa Province, Shimofusa Province, Awa Province)
Fusa Province (Kazusa Province, Shimofusa Province, Awa Province)
Fusa Province (Kazusa Province, Shimofusa Province, Awa Province)

sen.j: 越国（越前国、加賀国、能登国、越中国、越後国、佐渡国、出羽国）
sen.e: Etsu Province (Echizen Province, Kaga Province, Noto Province, Ecchu Province, Echigo Province, Sado Province, Dewa Province)
Koshi Province (Echizen Province, Kaga Province, Noto Province, Ecchu Province, Echigo Province, Sado Province, Dewa Province)
Koshi Province (Echizen Province, Kaga Province, Noto Province, Ecchu Province, Echigo Province, Sado Province, Dewa Province)

sen.j: 丹波国（但馬国、丹後国を分離）
sen.e: Tanba Province (that separated Tajima and Tanba Provinces)
Tanba Province (that separated Tajima and Tango Provinces)
Tanba Province (that separated Tajima and Tango Provinces)

sen.j: 伊勢国（志摩国を分離）
sen.e: Ise Province (that separated Shima Province)
Ise Province (that separated Shima Province)
Ise Province (that separated Shima Province)

sen.j: 河内国（和泉国を分離）
sen.e: Kauchi Province (that separated Izumi Province)
Kawachi Province (that separated Izumi Province)
Kawachi Province (that separated Izumi Province)

sen.j: 吉備国（備前国、美作国、備中国、備後国）
sen.e: Kibi Province (Bizen Province, Mimasaka Province, Bicchu Province, Bingo Province)
Kibi Province (Bizen Province, Mimasaka Province, Bicchu Province, Bingo Province)
Kibi Province (Bizen Province, Mimasaka Province, Bicchu Province, Bingo Province)

sen.j: 筑紫国（筑前国、筑後国）
sen.e: Chikushi Province (Chikuzen Province, Chikugo Province)
Tsukushi Province (Chikuzen Province, Chikugo Province)
Tsukushi Province (Chikuzen Province, Chikugo Province)

sen.j: 肥国（肥前国、肥後国）
sen.e: Hi Province (Hizen Province, Higo Province)
Hi Province (Hizen Province, Higo Province)
Hi Province (Hizen Province, Higo Province)

sen.j: 豊国（豊前国、豊後国）
sen.e: Toyo Province (Buzen Province, Bungo Province)
Toyo Province (Buzen Province, Bungo Province)
Toyo Province (Buzen Province, Bungo Province)

sen.j: 熊襲（? 日向国成立後、薩摩国、大隅国を分離）
sen.e: Kumaso (? after Hyuga Province establishment, separated Satsuma Province and Osumi Province)
Kumaso (? Satsuma and Osumi Provinces were separated after Hyuga Province was established)
Kumaso (? Satsuma and Osumi Provinces were separated after Hyuga Province was established)

sen.j: 律令制下
sen.e: Under the Ritsu Ryo system
Under the Ritsuryo Codes
Under the Ritsuryo Codes

sen.j: 奈良時代初期の713年（和銅6）に、元明天皇は、令制国毎に「風土記」という地誌の編纂を命じた。
sen.e: In 713, the first half of Nara period, Emperor Genmyo ordered the compilation of regional gazetteers or topography (fudoki in Japanese) by each ryosei province.
In 713, the early Nara period, Emperor Genmyo ordered the compilation of regional gazetteers or topography called 'Fudoki' for each ryosei province.
In 713, the early Nara period, Emperor Genmyo ordered the compilation of regional gazetteers or topography called 'Fudoki' for each ryosei province.

sen.j: 現在、出雲国風土記、常陸国風土記、播磨国風土記、肥前国風土記、豊後国風土記の物が、一部残存している。
sen.e: Presently, parts of the following regional gazetteers including Izumo Province fudoki, Hitachi Province fudoki. Harima Province fudoki, Hizen Province fudoki, Bungo Province fudoki and Bungo Province fudoki are existent.
Presently, parts of Izumo Province Fudoki, Hitachi Province Fudoki, Harima Province Fudoki, Hizen Province Fudoki and Bungo Province Fudoki are existent.
sen.cmt: ・the following regional gazetteers includingを削除しました・重複するbungo province fudokiを削除しました
sen.e: Presently, parts of Izumo Province Fudoki, Hitachi Province Fudoki, Harima Province Fudoki, Hizen Province Fudoki and Bungo Province Fudoki are existent.

sen.j: 同年5月に畿内と七道諸国の郡（こおり）・郷（さと）の名に好字（よいじ）を付けるように命じた。
sen.e: In May, the same year, the Imperial Court ordered to put " good characters for name " (yoi ji in Japanese) to each county and village in provinces near capital and in seven prefectures.
In May of the same year, the Imperial Court ordered to put yoi-ji (good character) to each kori (county) and sato (village) in provinces near capital and in seven prefectures.
sen.cmt: ・In May, the same year→In May of the same year・その他改変しました
sen.e: In May of the same year, the Imperial Court ordered to put yoi-ji (good character) to each kori (county) and sato (village) in provinces near capital and in seven prefectures.

sen.j: 全国の国名が漢字2文字に統一されている。
sen.e: As of present, provincial names all over Japan are unified in 2 characters.
As of present, provincial names all over Japan are unified in 2 characters.
As of present, provincial names all over Japan are unified in 2 characters.

sen.j: 738年（天平10）諸国の国郡図を進上させる。
sen.e: In 738, the Imperial Court ordered to submit charts of province and county throughout the country.
In 738, the Imperial Court ordered to submit charts of province and county throughout the country.
In 738, the Imperial Court ordered to submit charts of province and county throughout the country.

sen.j: 739年（天平11）年末頃から740年（天平12）初めの頃に郷里制を郷制に改める。
sen.e: During the period from the end of 736 to the first of 740, the Imperial Court revised the district and village system to the district system.
During the period from the end of 736 to the beginning of 740, the Imperial Court revised the go-ri sei (township-neighbourhood system) to go-sei.
During the period from the end of 736 to the beginning of 740, the Imperial Court revised the go-ri sei (township-neighbourhood system) to go-sei.

sen.j: 740年代に聖武天皇が政権に就いた時期には、平城京では疫病が蔓延し、社会不安が広がっていた。
sen.e: In 740s, the period when Emperor Shoumu acceded to the throne, an epidemic was prevalent and social anxiety was spreading in Heijokyo Capital.
In 740s, the period when Emperor Shoumu acceded to the throne, an epidemic was prevalent and social anxiety was spreading in Heijokyo Capital.
In 740s, the period when Emperor Shoumu acceded to the throne, an epidemic was prevalent and social anxiety was spreading in Heijokyo Capital.

sen.j: これを払拭すべく、光明皇后の意見も有って、741年（天平13）令制国には国分寺（国分僧寺）・国分尼寺の建立の詔を出した。
sen.e: To clear up the uneasiness, also with the opinion of the empress consort Komyo, in 741, the Emperor issued the imperial proclamation to establish provincial temples and provincial nunneries in ryosei provinces.

To clear up the uneasiness, also with the opinion of the empress Komyo, in 741, the Emperor issued the imperial proclamation to establish provincial temples and provincial nunneries in ryosei provinces.

To clear up the uneasiness, also with the opinion of the empress Komyo, in 741, the Emperor issued the imperial proclamation to establish provincial temples and provincial nunneries in ryosei provinces.

sen.j: 800年頃に出された延喜式には、各令制国における郡の個数が記載された。
sen.e: In the Engi formality issued around in 800, number of counties in each Ryosei province was written.
In the Engi formality issued around 800, the number of counties in each Ryosei province was written.
sen.cmt: around in 800, number of→around 800, the number of
sen.e: In the Engi formality issued around 800, the number of counties in each Ryosei province was written.

sen.j: 中近世
sen.e: Middle and early-modern times
Middle and Early-modern Period
Middle and Early-modern Period

sen.j: 律令制が事実上崩壊してからも、鎌倉時代においては、依然として各国に国衙が置かれ、国を支配していた。
sen.e: In Kamakura period, even after the Ritsuryo system virtually collapsed, Kokuga (administrative organ) was still placed in each province and controlled the province.
In Kamakura period, even after the Ritsuryo system virtually collapsed, Kokuga (administrative organ) was still placed in each province and controlled it.
In Kamakura period, even after the Ritsuryo system virtually collapsed, Kokuga (administrative organ) was still placed in each province and controlled it.

sen.j: 南北朝時代 (日本)に戦乱が全国に及ぶと、守護大名の力が増大し、国衙も支配するようになった。
sen.e: In the period of the Northern and Southern Dynasties, when disturbances of war spread throughout the country, military governors (shugo daimyo) increased their power and started to govern Kokuga or local administrative organ.
In the period of the Northern and Southern Dynasties, when disturbances of war spread throughout the country, shugo daimyo (military governors) increased their power and started to govern Kokuga.
sen.cmt: ・military governors (shugo daimyo) →shugo daimyo (military governors)・ or local administrative organを削除しました（前列にすでに説明があるので）
sen.e: In the period of the Northern and Southern Dynasties, when disturbances of war spread throughout the country, shugo daimyo (military governors) increased their power and started to govern Kokuga.

sen.j: それにともない室町時代には守護による守護領国制支配が進行した。
sen.e: Along with it, in the Muromachi period, the military governors' territory (fief) system made progress.
Along with it, in the Muromachi period, the territory (fief) system of shugo made progress.
sen.cmt: the military governors’ territory (fief) system→the territory (fief) system of shugo
sen.e: Along with it, in the Muromachi period, the territory (fief) system of shugo made progress.

sen.j: 戦国時代 (日本)になると、律令時代からの行政体としての国は消滅した。
sen.e: In the turbulent times, provinces as administrative organs since Ritsuryo period disappeared.
In the Sengoku period, provinces as administrative organs since Ritsuryo period disappeared.
sen.cmt: In the turbulent times→In the Sengoku period
sen.e: In the Sengoku period, provinces as administrative organs since Ritsuryo period disappeared.

sen.j: 国司は、完全に名目だけの官職となり、戦国大名が領国支配の正当性を主張するために欲するようになる。
sen.e: The post of provincial governor became perfectly the nominal official post and warlords came to want that post in order to insist the legitimacy of controlling their territories.
The post of provincial governor became perfectly the nominal, and warlords came to want that post in order to insist the legitimacy of controlling their territories.
sen.cmt: official post を削除しました（文頭と重複するので）
sen.e: The post of provincial governor became perfectly the nominal, and warlords came to want that post in order to insist the legitimacy of controlling their territories.

sen.j: 安土桃山時代と江戸時代には、地方統治は大小多様の大名と、大名に準ずる領主、江戸幕府の直轄領に分割された。
sen.e: In Azuchi-Momoyama period and Edo period, the control of local areas was divided by daimyos of various sizes, feudal lords equivalent to daimyos and direct control of Edo shogunate.
In Azuchi-Momoyama period and Edo period, the control of local areas was divided by daimyos of various sizes, feudal lords equivalent to daimyos and direct control of Edo shogunate.
In Azuchi-Momoyama period and Edo period, the control of local areas was divided by daimyos of various sizes, feudal lords equivalent to daimyos and direct control of Edo shogunate.

sen.j: 領有が細分化した地方に特別な機関を置く場合を除いて、国を単位とする行政体はなかった（ただし国司を任じていたことから、名目のみ行政区分としての令制国は存在していた）。
sen.e: Except for particular cases, there were no administrative organs based on the province (However, dynasty appointed provincial governors, therefore, there were Ryosei provinces as nominal administrative division).

Except for the cases in which particular organization was placed on the district where territories were segmentalized, there were no administrative organs based on the province (However, as dynasty appointed provincial governors, there were Ryosei provinces as nominal administrative division).
sen.cmt: ・「領有が細分化した地方に特別な機関を置く」を訳出・However, dynasty appointed provincial governors, therefore, →However, as dynasty appointed provincial governors,
sen.e: Except for the cases in which particular organization was placed on the district where territories were segmentalized, there were no administrative organs based on the province (However, as dynasty appointed provincial governors, there were Ryosei provinces as nominal administrative division).

sen.j: しかし、戸籍等の住所の表示には令制国が用いられ、欠かせない地理区分であった。
sen.e: But Ryosei province was used for indication of address including family register and indispensable geographical division.
But Ryosei province was used for indication of address including family register, thus it was indispensable geographical division.
sen.cmt: and indispensable geographical division→, thus it was indispensable geographical division
sen.e: But Ryosei province was used for indication of address including family register, thus it was indispensable geographical division.

sen.j: 明治以後
sen.e: After Meiji period
After the Meiji Period
After the Meiji Period

sen.j: 江戸時代までとの大きな違いは国司を廃止したことであり、国司廃止によって名実共に行政的な地理区分ではなくなってしまった。
sen.e: The big difference in Meiji period from the time until Edo period, was the abolition of provincial governors, and with the provincial governor abolition, Ryosei province system finished the function of administrative geographical division.

The big difference in Meiji period from the time until Edo period, was the abolition of provincial governors with which Ryosei province system finished its function of administrative geographical division namely and actually.
sen.cmt: ・, and with the provincial governor abolition, →with which・「名実共に」を訳出
sen.e: The big difference in Meiji period from the time until Edo period, was the abolition of provincial governors with which Ryosei province system finished its function of administrative geographical division namely and actually.

sen.j: 明治政府は、陸奥国から4国を分立させ、出羽国を2国に分割し、北海道 (令制)に11国を新設し、さらに琉球国を置いて85国としたが、国単位での行政機関を置かなかった。
sen.e: The Meiji government separated 4 provinces from Mutsu Province, divided Dewa Province into 2 provinces, newly established 11 provinces in Hokkaido, and in addition, established Ryukyu Province, setting up 85 provinces in total, but it did not found administrative organs in every province.

The Meiji government separated 4 provinces from Mutsu Province, divided Dewa Province into 2 provinces, newly established 11 provinces in Hokkaido and established Ryukyu Province to set up 85 provinces in total, but it did not found administrative organs in every province.
sen.cmt: and in addition, established Ryukyu Province, setting up 85 provinces in total→and established Ryukyu Province to set up 85 provinces in total
sen.e: The Meiji government separated 4 provinces from Mutsu Province, divided Dewa Province into 2 provinces, newly established 11 provinces in Hokkaido and established Ryukyu Province to set up 85 provinces in total, but it did not found administrative organs in every province.

sen.j: 1871年の廃藩置県は藩を廃止したもので、国はその後も府県と併用された。
sen.e: The abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures in 1871 aimed at the abolition of feudal domains, and provinces continued to be used together with prefectures after that.
The abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures in 1871 aimed at the abolition of feudal domains, and provinces continued to be used together with prefectures after that.
The abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures in 1871 aimed at the abolition of feudal domains, and provinces continued to be used together with prefectures after that.

sen.j: 1885年までは北海道において令制国の範囲改定が行われたりしていたことから少なくともこの年までは制度上も用いられていた.
sen.e: The abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures in 1871 aimed at the abolition of feudal domains, and provinces continued to be used together with prefectures after that.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の」例外対処
sen.e: The range of ryosei province in Hokkaido was revised until 1885; this shows ryosei province had been institutionally used at least until this year.
sen.cmt: 前列のコピーになっています→全体を訳し直し
sen.e: The range of ryosei province in Hokkaido was revised until 1885; this shows ryosei province had been institutionally used at least until this year.

sen.j: しかし、それ以降領有した日本統治時代 (台湾)・日本統治時代の朝鮮などの外地に新たな令制国は設定されなかった。
sen.e: However, after that, in Taiwan and in Korea in the age under the rule of Japan, new ryosei province was not established.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の」例外対処
sen.e: However, after that, in Taiwan and in Korea in the age under the rule of Japan, new ryosei province was not established.
However, after that, in Taiwan and in Korea in the age under the rule of Japan, new ryosei province was not established.

sen.j: 法令による廃止はされていないが、とりわけ戸籍・郵便等の地名表記から外されたことにより急速に廃れ、反対に府県は急速に定着した。
sen.e: Although not abolished by law, the Ryosei system rapidly became obsolete, especially with being excluded from place-name writing, and on the contrary, prefecture system was rapidly established.
Although not abolished by law, the Ryosei system rapidly became obsolete, especially with being excluded from place-name writing, and on the contrary, prefecture system was rapidly established.
Although not abolished by law, the Ryosei system rapidly became obsolete, especially with being excluded from place-name writing, and on the contrary, prefecture system was rapidly established.

sen.j: 現代では、同じ地名を呼び分けるときや（摂津本山駅←→長門本山駅など）、都道府県名を嫌う場合（長野県←→信州など）、地域名（泉州、筑豊など）、地域ブランド名など（讃岐うどん、但馬牛、薩摩焼など）に旧国名が利用されている。
sen.e: At the present time, old province names are used in cases such as distinguishing similar place-names (ex. Settsu Motoyama and Nagato Motoyama), avoiding the use of prefecture name (ex. Nagano prefecture and Shinshu), and expressing local specialty, or noted product (ex. Sanuki noodle, Tajima cattle, Satsuma ware).

At the present time, old province names are used in cases such as distinguishing similar place-names (ex. Settsu Motoyama and Nagato Motoyama), avoiding the use of prefecture name (ex. Shinshu against Nagano prefecture), and expressing local specialty or noted product (ex. Sanuki noodle, Tajima cattle, Satsuma ware).
sen.cmt: ・（）内の余分なスペースを削除・ex. Nagano prefecture and Shinshu→Shinshu against Nagano prefecture
sen.e: At the present time, old province names are used in cases such as distinguishing similar place-names (ex. Settsu Motoyama and Nagato Motoyama), avoiding the use of prefecture name (ex. Shinshu against Nagano prefecture), and expressing local specialty or noted product (ex. Sanuki noodle, Tajima cattle, Satsuma ware).

sen.j: また、北海道条例･国法においては「法務局及び地方法務局の支局及び出張所設置規則」において、支庁や法務局およびその下部組織の所管区域を示す規定中に令制国が示されているものもある。
sen.e: Further, regarding the national law and Hokkaido ordinance, in the" establishment rule for the regal affairs bureau and branch offices of the local regal affairs bureau ", some rules provide the expression of " ryosei province."

Further, regarding the national law and Hokkaido ordinance, in the 'establishment rule for branch offices of the legal affairs bureau and the local legal affairs bureau', some rules provide the expression of ryosei province in the stipulation which showed presiding areas of subprefecture, the legal affairs bureau and its lower organizations.
sen.cmt: ・ establishment rule for the regal affairs bureau and branch offices of the local regal affairs bureau “→'establishment rule for branch offices of the legal affairs bureau and the local legal affairs bureau'・「支庁や法務局およびその下部組織の所管区域を示す規定中に」を訳出
sen.e: Further, regarding the national law and Hokkaido ordinance, in the 'establishment rule for branch offices of the legal affairs bureau and the local legal affairs bureau', some rules provide the expression of ryosei province in the stipulation which showed presiding areas of subprefecture, the legal affairs bureau and its lower organizations.

sen.j: 令制国は、奈良時代までと明治時代に大きな改廃がなされたが、その間の平安時代から江戸時代までの長期にわたって変更がなかった。
sen.e: The rules for Ryosei province were greatly amended in Nara and Meiji periods, but they were not changed in the long term between Heian period and Edo period.
The rules for Ryosei province were greatly amended before the Nara period and in the Meiji period, but they were not changed in the long term between Heian period and Edo period.
sen.cmt: in Nara and Meiji periods→before the Nara period and in the Meiji period
sen.e: The rules for Ryosei province were greatly amended before the Nara period and in the Meiji period, but they were not changed in the long term between Heian period and Edo period.

sen.j: その数は68であるが、66とされることも多かった。
sen.e: The number of Ryosei provinces was usually 68, but in many cases, it was said to be 66.
The number of Ryosei provinces was usually 68, but in many cases, it was said to be 66.
The number of Ryosei provinces was usually 68, but in many cases, it was said to be 66.

sen.j: （この場合、対馬・壱岐国が「嶋」としてはずれる）例えば11か国を守護領国とした山名氏は、全国の六分の一の国を領したという意味で「六分一殿」と呼ばれた。
sen.e: (in this case, Tsushima and Iki provinces were excluded as islands). For example, the Yamana clan that had 11 provinces as military daimyo as its territory was called " One Sixth Esquire ", because it possessed one sixth area of the whole country.

(in this case, Tsushima and Iki provinces were excluded as islands) For example, the Yamana clan that had 11 provinces as shugo's territory was called " One Sixth Esquire ", because it possessed one sixth of the provinces of whole country.
sen.cmt: ・as military daimyo as its territory→hugo's territory・one sixth area of the whole country→one sixth of the provinces of whole country
sen.e: (in this case, Tsushima and Iki provinces were excluded as islands) For example, the Yamana clan that had 11 provinces as shugo's territory was called " One Sixth Esquire ", because it possessed one sixth of the provinces of whole country.

sen.j: 「全国一宮一覧」など全ての国を列挙するような場合には、実際の国の数と合わないので、備前・備中・備後をまとめて吉備とする（ただし、備前から分かれた美作はそのまま）など無理に2国減らして66にすることも行われた。
sen.e: In some case of enumerating all province names throughout the nation, a measure was taken to reduce the number of provinces to 66 by integrating provinces, for example, Bizen, Bicchu and Bingo into one province with the name of Kibi (but Mimasaka province which was separated from Bizen province, was not integrated).

In some case of enumerating all province names such as 'the list of Ichinomiya shrine throughout the nation', two provinces forcedly reduced to 66 due to the incompliance with the acutual number of the province by integrating, for example, Bizen, Bicchu and Bingo into Kibi province(but Mimasaka province which was separated from Bizen province, was not integrated).
sen.cmt: 「全国一宮一覧」を訳出、ほか一部改変しました
sen.e: In some case of enumerating all province names such as 'the list of Ichinomiya shrine throughout the nation', two provinces forcedly reduced to 66 due to the incompliance with the acutual number of the province by integrating, for example, Bizen, Bicchu and Bingo into Kibi province(but Mimasaka province which was separated from Bizen province, was not integrated).

sen.j: 「六十余州」と表現することもあった。
sen.e: In some case, they used the expression of " over 60 provinces. "
In some case, they used the expression of 'over 60 provinces.'
sen.cmt: 引用符を改変しました
sen.e: In some case, they used the expression of 'over 60 provinces.'
